author: Staff Reporter
text:
The Madras High Court has ordered detention of a Dominican vessel anchored in Karaikal port, noting that it would be impossible to recover Rs. 30 crore which the ship owes to the Indian Bank if it is allowed to leave the port.

Justice K.K. Sasidharan ordered the detention of the ship “CSD Marg Cauvery” while passing interim orders on a petition moved by the Indian Bank.

According to the bank, the ship owner had obtained a loan from the Singapore branch of Indian Bank by mortgaging the valuables of the ship.

“Marg India’s subsidiary company in Singapore, had availed a loan of 8.3 million dollars in August 2009. Among other conditions, the owner was mandated to repay the loan in full by 20 equal instalments.

The first instalment was made on November 21, 2009. Later, the company submitted several proposals for settling the dues by bringing in another investor, but the bank rejected them. Now the company owes Rs 29.31 crore to the bank,” the petitioner said.

Within the jurisdiction

Since the ship is stationed in Karaikal port, which is within the jurisdiction of Madras High Court the bank has approached the court for the vessel’s detention.

Admitting the petition, the judge noted that Indian Bank is a nationalised bank dealing with public money.

Hence, it would be appropriate to order the vessel’s arrest at Karaikal or wherever found within the territorial waters of India and posted the matter for further hearing on January 20.

The ship owner had obtained a loan from the Singapore branch of

Indian Bank
title: HC orders detention of Dominican vessel
